author: By Mekita Rivas
title: Where Are All the Wedding D.J.s?
description: After months of couples postponing and paring down their wedding plans, the season of celebrating nuptials is finally in full swing again and D.J.s are in high demand and in short supply.
content: With more than 20 D.J.s on his roster at any given moment, Gary Hoffmann, who runs a D.J. company, cannot recall a single time he has had to turn an engaged couple away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: To Repeat Myself
description: Ruth Bloomfield Margolin breaks out the long-handled forks.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Ruth Bloomfield Margolin on this delightful Tuesday puzzle, which comes with a touching and hunger-inspiring back story (see Ms. Margolin’s notes at the bottom). This is Ms. Margolin’s 13th New York Times Crossword puzzle and her second Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Over 5 million Americans could soon be eligible for Covid vaccine booster shots.
description: The Food and Drug Administration must decide that third shots are safe and effective for Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, the two vaccines that were rolled out first and have been most used.
content: More than five million Americans could be eligible for booster shots of the Covid-19 vaccine by late September under the Biden administration’s plan to combat the Delta variant of the coronavirus by giving extra doses eight months after initial vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
description: The second round of funding for the year totals $28.4 million and will support 239 projects across the country.
content: The Morgan Library & Museum, the University of Chicago and the new Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., are among 239 beneficiaries of new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities that were announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Job vacancies in Britain hit a record high as wages climb and unemployment falls.
description: Employers coming out of lockdown competed to hire workers as the jobless rate fell to 4.7 percent from 4.9 percent.
content: Job vacancies in Britain climbed to a record high at the start of the summer as businesses competed with one another to fill positions after the government lifted pandemic restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Wildfire Terms Defined: What It Means When a Blaze Is 30 Percent Contained
description: Here’s how to understand what firefighters are saying when they talk about “red flag conditions” fueling the “extreme fire behavior” of a “complex fire.”
content: Many areas of the United States, especially the West, are in the cross hairs of devastating wildfires again this year. Amid a summer of searing temperatures and dry winds, firefighters have for weeks tried to contain one escalating fire after another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Biden defends the withdrawal from Afghanistan.
content: In an address from the White House, President Biden insisted that the U.S. mission in Afghanistan “was never supposed to have been about nation-building,” and said that there was no easy time to withdraw, even as he acknowledged that the retreat had been “hard and messy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand begins a three-day lockdown after a single case is reported.
description: The country has since reported seven cases in total of the Delta variant.
content: New Zealand began a three-day nationwide lockdown after reporting its first coronavirus case in six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: ‘Lots of prayers’ in Susanville, the largest town to be threatened by the Dixie fire.
description: Even as the flames grew closer, the town was fighting to keep a state prison and preserve its economic base.
content: As the Dixie fire has burned through Northern California over the past month, the city of Susanville in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada has become a refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Janet Yellen is getting another chance to shape the future of the Federal Reserve.
description: Jerome H. Powell’s term as chair of the Federal Reserve ends in February. Slots for the vice chair and the Fed’s top bank regulator will also be up for grabs soon, and a position on the Fed’s Board of Governors is already vacant.
content: Jerome H. Powell’s term as chair of the Federal Reserve ends in February. Slots for the vice chair and the Fed’s top bank regulator will also be up for grabs soon, and a position on the Fed’s Board of Governors is already vacant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: U.S. to Advise Boosters for Most Americans 8 Months After Vaccination
description: Nursing home residents and health care workers will most likely be the first to get booster shots, as soon as September, followed by other older people who were vaccinated last winter.
content: The Biden administration has decided that most Americans should get a coronavirus booster vaccination eight months after they received their second shot, and could begin offering third shots as early as the third week of September, according to administration officials familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: He Stayed Afloat Selling $3 Tacos. Now He Faces $2,000 in Fines.
description: People who lost jobs in the pandemic began to peddle food and wares to survive, but New York City is starting to crack down on unlicensed vendors.
content: Like thousands of New Yorkers, Lucio González lost his job in the pandemic. As an undocumented immigrant, he did not qualify for unemployment benefits or stimulus checks, so he began selling beef barbacoa tacos on Fordham Road in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: ‘It Happened So Fast’: Inside a Fatal Tesla Autopilot Accident
description: A 2019 crash in Florida highlights how gaps in Tesla’s driver-assistance system and distractions can have tragic consequences.
content: George Brian McGee, a finance executive in Florida, was driving home in a Tesla Model S operating on Autopilot, a system that can steer, brake and accelerate a car on its own, when he dropped his phone during a call and bent down to look for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Did America Betray Afghanistan?
description: The country is in many ways worse off than it was 20 years ago. What does America owe the Afghan people?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly’s Last Criminal Trial Was in 2008. The World Has Changed Since.
description: The R&B artist was acquitted 13 years ago. But the culture around allegations of sexual misconduct has shifted dramatically since then, and he faces more formidable charges this time.
content: Twenty five years ago, a woman in Chicago sued the singer R. Kelly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Roiphe
title: The Authors of ‘The Madwoman in the Attic’ Are Back With a New (Angry) Book
description: In their new work, Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar, the feminist scholars who wrote the 1979 classic, examine literary manifestations of feminist anger from the second half of the 20th century to today.
content: STILL MADAmerican Women Writers and the Feminist ImaginationBy Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Get Afghan Refugees Out. Then Let Them In.
description: America has a moral duty to help as many people threatened by the Taliban as it possibly can.
content: There are no good ways to lose a war, but the way America has lost Afghanistan should fill every one of us with shame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Afghanistan, Vietnam and the Limits of American Power
description: The fall of Kabul is not the fall of Saigon. But historians still point to some useful parallels and lessons.
content: “Saigon.” Even those who weren’t alive to watch America’s ignominious exit from South Vietnam in 1975 can conjure the image: a helicopter perched atop an apartment building, loaded with evacuees, a photographic memorial for the country’s defeat and a sign of the wrenching political and cultural reckoning that was to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Maggie Q Nourishes Herself With Local Produce and ‘Dateline’
description: The actress talks about her latest movie, “The Protégé,” her fascination with “American Gigolo,” her dedication to rescue dogs, and the joy of Asian stand-up and soup.
content: Onscreen, Maggie Q specializes in hard-core power women, snapping necks, spraying bullets and showing no fear in thrillers like “Nikita” and “Designated Survivor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Five Census Findings You May Have Missed
description: California ranks as the second-most diverse state in the nation as its white population shrinks. Plus, San Francisco is the country’s most childless big city.
content: By now, you have probably heard that California, while still the country’s most populous state by far, isn’t growing as quickly as the rest of the nation. The reversal of a decades-long boom, which will strip California of a congressional seat for the first time, was initially documented in a preview of census data this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Accessibility Is a Right. This Restaurant Treats It That Way.
description: Contento, in East Harlem, sets an example for an industry that is rarely welcoming to diners with disabilities.
content: As I write each week’s restaurant review, I call an owner to ask whether somebody in a wheelchair would be able to enter the dining room and enjoy a meal. By that time, I’ve already eaten there and spent a few minutes looking around for features that might make a space inaccessible, like steps, narrow passageways and small restrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Thousands of Afghans who helped the U.S. are trapped. What happens next?
description: Many of those who worked alongside U.S. troops have waited years for visas to come to the United States. The speedy withdrawal of forces left most of them behind.
content: Tens of thousands of Afghan nationals risked their lives to help the United States military in Afghanistan, many of them working as interpreters in combat. Now, after the Taliban’s takeover, they are desperate to leave — but passage to the United States may prove elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: House Democrats introduce a bill to beef up the Voting Rights Act.
description: The House plans to vote on it next week, but Republicans promise to block it in the Senate.
content: Democrats on Tuesday unveiled a long-awaited linchpin of their drive to protect voting rights, introducing legislation that would make it easier for the federal government to block state election rules found to be discriminatory to nonwhite voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: How Peppers Proliferated Around the Planet
description: In the world’s plant gene banks, scientists studied how so many varieties of the humble capsicum worked their way onto our plates.
content: Peppers are cosmopolitan, a vegetable that comes in far more varieties than there are nations in the world. One day you can slice a mild orange bell pepper to dip in hummus. Another you may roast red peppers and blend them into a dip or a sauce of their own, like ajvar or romesco. Poblano peppers can add some heat to a dish, or even become a meal like chile rellenos. But watch out for those Carolina Reaper peppers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Breed Fruit Flies
description: Anesthetize them with carbon dioxide. Sort males from females. Use virgins.
content: “Make sure you use flies that haven’t bred before,” says Christina Lim, 28, who spent years breeding and feeding fruit flies at the NASA Ames Research Center near Mountain View, Calif., in preparation for the insects’ 2017 flight to the International Space Station. Data from those flies showed that spaceflight caused serious structural and biochemical changes to their hearts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Los Angeles to Require Masks at Large Outdoor Concerts and Events
description: The order comes as the spread of the Delta variant has driven up caseloads.
content: Facing a continuing increase in coronavirus cases, Los Angeles County said Tuesday that it would require masks be worn at large outdoor concerts and sporting events that attract more than 10,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Colbert on Afghanistan: ‘It’s Heartbreaking’
description: “Why should our soldiers be fighting radicals in a civil war in Afghanistan? We’ve got our own on Capitol Hill,” Stephen Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kawai Strong Washburn
title: Vinod Busjeet’s Debut Sets an Origin Story on the Island of Mauritius
description: In “Silent Wind, Dry Seas,” a man of Indian descent leaves his country behind to chase an American ideal of success.
content: SILENT WINDS, DRY SEAS By Vinod Busjeet
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Dan Bilefsky
title: For Afghan Women, Taliban Stir Fears of Return to a Repressive Past
description: Since the U.S. ousted the Taliban, women and girls have rejoined society in ways that would have been unimaginable under their rule. Now those gains are threatened.
content: As Afghan women cloistered in their homes on Tuesday, fearing for their lives and their futures under Taliban rule, a pair of female television broadcasters offered starkly contradictory visions of the country’s direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: My Puzzling Entry in the Crypto World
description: I created a hype coin to show how risky an investment can be. The coin had other plans.
content: When I conducted a little experiment recently for an article to highlight a corner of the cryptocurrency world, I knew I was creating something that would live on after the piece was published. But what happened still took me by surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and J. David Goodman
title: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: The governor, a Republican who is fully vaccinated, will now be isolated in the Governor’s Mansion while receiving medical treatment.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday and is receiving an antibody treatment, though he has no symptoms, the governor’s office announced.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 17, 2021.
content: A picture caption with an article on Saturday about police killings in rural America misspelled the given name of a niece of Bradley Grant, a man who was shot in 2018 by a Kentucky detective. It is Natilee, not Natalie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Jackson
title: How Will the Taliban Rule? Here’s the Early Evidence.
description: This is what Taliban control looks like in 2021.
content: For all the recriminations and finger-pointing about how the Taliban gained control of Afghanistan so rapidly, there is a hard truth that needs to be reckoned with: The Taliban have spent years preparing for the eventual U.S. withdrawal. Despite numerous military surges, relentless airstrikes and thousands killed on all sides, no one was able to stop them. Year by year, Taliban soldiers methodically gained ground as they coerced and co-opted large swaths of the population now living under their rule and set up a shadow state. The Taliban exploited anger at the abuses of foreign forces and Afghan government corruption to gain support in village after village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The Taliban consolidate power.
content: Taliban leaders took to Twitter, appeared on international cable networks and held a news conference to provide assurances that they would not carry out reprisal killings or seize property, following their takeover in Afghanistan. At their first news conference, a spokesperson said they would allow women to work and study — but “within the bounds of Islamic law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Hisako Ueno
title: Maki Kaji, the ‘Godfather of Sudoku,’ Is Dead at 69
description: Mr. Kaji, a university dropout, turned a numbers game into one of the world’s most popular logic puzzles.
content: Maki Kaji, a university dropout who turned a numbers game into one of the world’s most popular logic puzzles and became known as the “Godfather of Sudoku,” died on Aug. 10 at his home in Tokyo. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Racial Inequities Persist in Health Care Despite Expanded Insurance
description: A series of studies in an influential medical journal takes a close look at longstanding gaps in medical care.
content: Two decades ago, only 9 percent of white Americans rated their health as fair or poor. But 14 percent of Hispanic Americans characterized their health in those terms, as did nearly 18 percent of Black Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Booster Shots, Sudoku: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Eskenazi
title: Joe Walton’s Jets Could Have Been the Best Team in the N.F.L.
description: The former Jets Coach Joe Walton has a stadium named after him, but not in the New York area. A sportswriter recalls the coach’s up-and-down pro tenure and how he found glory, and peace, elsewhere.
content: Joe Walton, who died on Sunday at age 85, presided over what I think of as “The Jets Era That Never Was.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Souvankham Thammavongsa
title: A Memoir’s Painful Question: Where Are You From?
description: “Names for Light,” by Thirii Myo Kyaw Myint, is a memoir recounted through the stories of family members.
content: NAMES FOR LIGHTA Family HistoryBy Thirii Myo Kyaw Myint
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney
title: Who Are the Taliban, and What Do They Want?
description: Here are answers to questions about the militants who have seized control in Afghanistan again, including their origin story, their record as rulers, and why so many women fear their return.
content: In the winter of 1995, a New York Times correspondent visiting Afghanistan reported that after years of brutal civil strife, a big change seemed to be afoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: U.S. veterans watch Afghan collapse with anguish, rage and relief.
description: “I just can’t help thinking about what a waste it is,” one veteran said. “I can’t allow myself to think about how after all that blood and treasure, it ends like this.”
content: Over the two decades the United States military fought in Afghanistan, more than 775,000 American troops served there, deployed to citylike air bases and to sandbag outposts on lonely mountaintops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The Atlanta Falcons claim an N.F.L. first: 100 percent of its players are vaccinated.
description: The achievement frees the team from some Covid restrictions, allowing players to eat and work out together and skip social distancing.
content: The Atlanta Falcons announced on Monday that the team’s players are all vaccinated against the coronavirus, becoming the first N.F.L. team to reach 100 percent. Achieving that threshold means that all players on the roster now enjoy more freedom and are not subject to certain restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
title: Can Gov. Newsom Keep His Job? A Recall Effort in California Shows a Dead Heat.
description: The vote is expected to come down to whether Democrats can mobilize enough of the state’s enormous base to counteract Republican enthusiasm for Gavin Newsom’s ouster.
content: President Biden sent an urgent message last week to the most populous state in the nation: Keep Gov. Gavin Newsom “on the job.” On the airwaves, Senator Elizabeth Warren, the prominent progressive from Massachusetts, has been repeatedly warning that “Trump Republicans” are “coming to grab power in California.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliott Holt
title: My Secret Weapon Against the Attention Economy
description: When you reread the same poem over and over again, you stop scrolling along the surface and dive deep beneath it.
content: Even before I could write, I was making up stories and songs. Or so my mother told me. She tape-recorded me reciting my creations and then typed them up. One piece, sung in 1979 when I was 5, reads in part:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Nossiter
title: After 7 years of failing to fix Afghanistan, Ghani made a hasty escape.
description: Western technocrat. Would-be populist. Wartime president. Ashraf Ghani tried to inhabit many roles during his years as Afghanistan’s president.
content: Western technocrat. Would-be populist. Wartime president. Ashraf Ghani tried to inhabit many roles during his years as Afghanistan’s president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Thompson
title: Billie Jean King: The First Female Athlete-Activist
description: In her new memoir, “All In,” King is as concerned with political and social issues as she is with tennis.
content: ALL INAn AutobiographyBy Billie Jean King with Johnette Howard and Maryanne Vollers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Hayhoe and Friederike Otto
title: What Cutting-Edge Science Can Tell Us About Extreme Weather
description: Advances in attribution science have made clear how climate change is making floods, fires and heat waves worse.
content: Hotter, faster, stronger: That isn’t a tagline for the next blockbuster superhero movie. This is what climate change is doing to many extreme weather events. As the planet warms, heat waves are getting hotter, wildfires are moving faster and burning larger areas, and storms and floods are becoming stronger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Review: Revisiting Four Nobodies in ‘[title of show]’
description: For an outdoor residency at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Bridge Production Group breathes fresh life into a 2004 musical.
content: The charm of the early internet era — before the web became an all-consuming necessity and was a seemingly innocent tool for promoting your work — survives in a new revival of “[title of show],” Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell’s autobiographical one-act musical from 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Eduardo Medina
title: The Dixie fire nears communities in the Sierra Nevada foothills.
description: The wildfire is one of at least six large ones burning in Northern California. High winds, low humidity and searing temperatures exacerbate the risk that fire will spread.
content: The Dixie fire, the second-largest in California’s recorded history, was wheeling on Tuesday toward one of the biggest urban targets in its path: the city of Susanville, population 15,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Saga, From the Crown Shy Team, to Open High Above the Financial District
description: A California ramen chain comes to the East Village, a beer garden for Oceana in Midtown, and more news.
content: The celebrated financial district restaurant Crown Shy, which reopened at 100 percent capacity in June, will grow by four stories by summer’s end. The restaurant has taken over four floors (62, 63, 64 and 66) at the top of 70 Pine Street, an Art Deco building. The spaces were used in the past by A.I.G. executives for board meetings, private dining and contract-signing ceremonies. They have been converted into this restaurant featuring experiential tasting menus ($245 per person, including tax and a welcome beverage); an elegant, oval cocktail bar called Overstory; and, at the very top, a private dining room. There are a total of 12 terraces with breathtaking views in every direction. Diners will get to see every inch of Saga, including the kitchen, as they are guided from room to room for each course of the executive chef James Kent’s meal. “Menus are conversations,” said Jeff Katz, the general manager and co-owner. “We’re trying to eliminate the standard come-into-the-restaurant, sit-at-the-table and start-the-meal-in-20-minutes format.” Customers need not dine at Saga to belly up to the brass-and-marble bar at the 24-seat Overstory, which is reached by a dramatic flight of stairs. It opens Aug. 24, with the private dining room opening later. ROBERT SIMONSON
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Taliban Promise Peace, but Doubt and Fear Persist
description: In their first statement since taking control, the Taliban hinted at a rule unlike their brutal regime a generation ago, trying to placate skeptics.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the first time since retaking power in Afghanistan, the Taliban’s leaders on Tuesday sketched out what their control of the country could look like, promising peace at home and urging the world to look past their history of violence and repression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How to Prep Kids for a Potentially Bumpy Return to School
description: Family vaccinations, universal masking, routines and compassion will be key.
content: As elementary school students return to in-person classes, parents are getting increasingly concerned about their kids’ safety. The Delta variant has caused a surge in pediatric Covid-19 hospitalizations, especially in areas with low vaccination rates. And some states aren’t mandating masks in classrooms, leaving parents uncertain about whether their kids should return at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Chucky Thompson, Hitmaking Producer, Is Dead at 53
description: He brought a range of musical influences to bear on the tracks he helped create for Mary J. Blige, the Notorious B.I.G. and many others.
content: “My mind is always on ‘Record,’” the producer Chucky Thompson once told an interviewer, explaining how he was able to bring such a wide range of musical influences to the hits he helped create for Mary J. Blige, the Notorious B.I.G., Nas and other stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: The Resilience of New York’s Black Homeowners
description: Black homeownership has declined in the city and nationally in the last 20 years, hindered by gentrification and inequitable lending policies.
content: Kirkland Lynch, a 35-year-old Black renter, has a six-figure job with Google, a law degree from Harvard, sterling credit and a mortgage pre-approval. But after a six-month house hunt in Brooklyn, with six unsuccessful bids, he is close to giving up, disheartened by slights that verge on discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Michael Moore joins other prominent writers on Substack.
description: His newsletter will be free, and readers will have the option to pay a subscription fee to access video chats and previews of his upcoming projects.
content: The filmmaker and left-wing provocateur Michael Moore has a new venue for his work: the digital newsletter platform Substack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: So, You’ve Been Cast as the Delta Variant
description: An ongoing meme personifies a highly contagious variant of the coronavirus as a saboteur.
content: When Spencer Pratt, a star of MTV’s “The Hills,” saw he was cast as the Delta variant of the coronavirus in a meme spreading across social media, he thought it was entertaining but also misleading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: 15% of Paycheck Protection Program Loans Could Be Fraudulent, Study Shows
description: Some $76 billion of the program’s $800 billion in loans may have been taken improperly, a new paper concludes.
content: When the Paycheck Protection Program began last year to help small businesses that were struggling during the pandemic, the federal government was determined to get the relief money out fast — so it waived much of the vetting lenders traditionally do on business loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Khmer Rouge Leader Appears in Court to Appeal Genocide Conviction
description: The trial is seen as the final stage of the long-running and expensive tribunal centered on the atrocities carried out in Cambodia during the 1970s.
content: The last living leader of the Khmer Rouge, the brutal Cambodian regime responsible for the deaths of at least 1.7 million people in the late 1970s, was in court Monday to appeal his conviction and life sentence for genocide and other crimes in what is seen as the final stage of the long-running and expensive tribunal centered on the atrocities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: The Secret to Finding That Off-Market Deal: ‘Be Prepared to Battle’
description: With listings appearing and disappearing overnight, buyers are turning to alternate sources to snag a home before it ever lands on the market.
content: In the spring of 2020, as people around the globe gave up the usual vices for the observance of Lent — sweets, alcohol, social media — Eric Atcheson gave up Zillow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: The Day After the Fall
description: A day after the collapse of the Afghan government, we’re looking at how the story is unfolding.
content: When the Taliban entered Afghanistan’s presidential palace on Sunday, the insurgent group completed a two-decade fight to take back control of the country. The president had fled; the interior minister announced there would be a peaceful transfer of power for greater Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: She Got Away With Murder, but Now the Past Is at Her Doorstep
description: The protagonist of Miranda Beverly-Whittemore’s novel “Fierce Little Thing” is drawn reluctantly back to the scene of the crime, the survivalist commune where she lived as a teenager.
content: Saskia, the unhappy protagonist of Miranda Beverly-Whittemore’s “Fierce Little Thing,” is full of secrets — some her own, some other people’s, many very grave indeed. A shut-in for more than a decade at home in Connecticut, she is startled, as the book begins, by the unexpected arrival of a group of old friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: The billionaire founder of China’s most indebted developer resigns as chairman of its real estate arm.
description: News of Xu Jiayin’s departure sent Evergrande’s shares tumbling and was another sign of Beijing’s efforts to rein in corporate debt.
content: The billionaire founder of Evergrande, China’s most indebted property developer, has stepped down from his position as chairman of the company’s main real estate arm, Hengda Real Estate Group, according to a notice filed to a government website on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams and Danilo Scarpati
title: A Painter’s Secret Roman Sanctuary
description: Roberto Ruspoli’s airy whitewashed studio in the attic of his childhood home is one big blank canvas.
content: There are times, while perched in his attic studio in Rome, when the Italian artist Roberto Ruspoli imagines he’s Cosimo in Italo Calvino’s novel “Baron in the Trees,” a character who exchanges his predictable life of privilege for one of his own making in the treetops. Some evenings, the 1,000-square-foot space, with its skeletal pitched ceiling of centuries-old wooden beams, reminds him of an ancient boat, the kind on which Odysseus might have journeyed home to Ithaca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Pete Buttigieg says he and his husband, Chasten, are now parents.
description: The transportation secretary said that the process was not yet complete but that he and his husband “can’t wait to share more soon.”
content: Pete Buttigieg, the U.S. transportation secretary, said on Tuesday that he and his husband, Chasten, were completing the process of becoming parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In a Handful of States, Early Data Hint at a Rise in Breakthrough Infections
description: With the arrival of the contagious Delta variant, Covid hospitalizations and deaths among vaccinated Americans also may have increased, according to preliminary figures.
content: Since Americans first began rolling up their sleeves for coronavirus vaccines, health officials have said that those who are immunized are very unlikely to become infected, or to suffer serious illness or death. But preliminary data from seven states hint that the arrival of the Delta variant in July may have altered the calculus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Winchester
title: Books That Cover Two Human Constants: Time and Motion
description: A review of Tom Standage’s “A Brief History of Motion” and David Rooney’s “About Time” delves into our concern with moving faster and checking our clocks.
content: A BRIEF HISTORY OF MOTIONFrom the Wheel, to the Car, to What Comes NextBy Tom Standage
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Who Created the Renewable-Energy Miracle?
description: Was it luck, or was it good policy?
content: This is a preview of the Paul Krugman newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams
title: When Kmart Moved Out, Churches and Flea Markets Moved In
description: The retailer’s former stores are being used by tenants that might not typically get a crack at such a large haul of commercial space at an affordable price.
content: When Kmart opened its first store, in Garden City, Mich., in 1962, the aim was to become an all-under-one-roof retailer. Americans’ shopping habits had gravitated toward the suburbs after World War II, and Kmart was going to cater to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: What to Do This Summer: Denver
description: Two neighborhoods and one arts district — LoDo, Five Points and RiNo — offer new hotels and restaurants, and plenty of cultural attractions that can be enjoyed outside.
content: While many Denver locals head for the hills in summer — as in the nearby Rocky Mountains — others know that sticking close to home can be just as satisfying in this active, outdoors-oriented city. As events, live music and Rockies baseball games regain their status as popular draws, and patios, alleyways and newly closed-off streets welcome diners and beer enthusiasts, Denver feels fairly back to normal amid the lingering pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: How ‘Woke’ Became an Insult
description: On the perils of the euphemism treadmill.
content: This is a preview of the John McWhorter newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Soprano With a Bottomless Appetite for Risk
description: The daring opera star Asmik Grigorian “could sing the phone book and it would be fabulous,” one director says.
content: BAYREUTH, Germany — Asmik Grigorian was hungry after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Brockman
title: Breathing Machine Recall Over Possible Cancer Risk Leaves Millions Scrambling for Substitutes
description: People with sleep apnea and other ailments who rely on CPAP and more than a dozen devices made by Philips are facing lengthy delays for replacements.
content: For three years, Donald Camp has used a breathing device to sleep. He has severe sleep apnea, so without this device, his breathing is obstructed and he gasps for air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center Hopes a $20 Million Donation Will Help Fuel a Revival
description: Eager for a comeback amid the pandemic, the center will distribute the gift to Jazz at Lincoln Center, Lincoln Center Theater, the Metropolitan Opera and New York City Ballet.
content: Lincoln Center announced on Tuesday that it would use a $20 million gift from the philanthropists Lynne and Richard Pasculano to help bring back and revitalize opera, jazz, theater and dance on its campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: What If You Could Become Invisible to Mosquitoes?
description: Using Crispr, scientists have taken the first step toward creating a mosquito that is blind to human hosts.
content: If you could have just one superpower, flight or invisibility, which would you choose? And would your answer change if you could become invisible to mosquitoes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaeah Lee
title: Why Was Vicha Ratanapakdee Killed?
description: His death helped awaken the nation to a rise in anti-Asian violence. For his grieving family, the reckoning hasn’t gone far enough.
content: For weeks, Monthanus Ratanapakdee urged her parents to please. stay inside. An uneasiness had hung over her ever since a mob descended on the Capitol early that month, though really, people had been acting crazy for a year. Throughout 2020, multiple strangers had come at her seemingly out of nowhere. That January, an old man yelled at her in Golden Gate Park — something about a virus and going back to her country — while she watched her sons, then 10 and 7, run in a playground. In February, two joggers, women, yelled something about germs at her older son as he played on a dock with a friend. In March, just before the country went into lockdown, a woman swung at Monthanus outside a hospital; she ducked the punch before running across the street. In November, another old man spat in her direction as her sons rode their scooters by the bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House leaders will press ahead with a vote to advance a $3.5 trillion budget plan.
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi plans to disregard warnings from moderate Democrats who want a vote on the infrastructure bill before the budget blueprint.
content: House Democratic leaders told members of their caucus on Tuesday that they plan to press ahead with a vote advancing a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint next week, disregarding warnings from moderate Democrats who said they will oppose that legislation without first voting on a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Smithsonian Acquires Rare Photographs From the First African American Studios
description: Daguerreotypes by James P. Ball, Glenalvin Goodridge and Augustus Washington are the centerpiece of a collection that could rewrite the early history of American photography.
content: Larry West was a mergers and acquisitions specialist when he happened upon an article in The New York Post in 1975 that said antique photographs were on the verge of becoming the next big collectible.  Inspired, he walked into a shop in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and came across a daguerreotype — an early form of photography, made on highly polished metal plates that is almost startling in its hologram-like effect. It depicted an African American man in a tuxedo, elegantly posed before the camera. West purchased it for $10.70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Overwhelmed by Coronavirus, Cuba’s Vaunted Health System Is Reeling
description: “The funeral homes can’t cope, the hospitals can’t cope, the clinics can’t cope,” said a Cuban doctor who was fired for publicly lamenting the distressed state of medical care.
content: Cuba’s health care system, long a source of national pride, is in acute distress, particularly in distant provinces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: After a Quarter-Century, the Queen of Salzburg Calls It Quits
description: Since 1995, Helga Rabl-Stadler has ruled the Salzburg Festival, classical music’s premier annual event, as its president and public face.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — It was intermission at the Salzburg Festival’s surreal and melancholy new production of “Don Giovanni,” and a small crowd of donors filled the office of Helga Rabl-Stadler, the festival’s president since 1995.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: George W. Bush says the events in Afghanistan fill him ‘with deep sadness.’
description: The former president, who ordered the invasion of Afghanistan that drove the Taliban from power two decades ago, said the U.S. had a “responsibility” to its Afghan allies.
content: President George W. Bush, who ordered the 2001 U.S.-led invasion that drove the Taliban from power, said this week that he felt “deep sadness” at the group’s takeover of Afghanistan and defended his decision to launch what would become America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: U.S. mask requirement for travelers is extended to January.
description: The mandate covers airports, as well as buses, trains and shuttle buses connected to airports, and all public buses, trains, subways and ferries.
content: A mask mandate in place for people visiting U.S. airports has been extended through Jan. 18, 2022, according to a statement on Tuesday from the Transportation Security Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Black in Ballet: Coming Together After Trying to ‘Blend Into the Corps’
description: A rare gathering of Black dancers from different companies meet to discuss a new production on Little Island, curated by Misty Copeland and Robert Garland.
content: Last year, in the wake of the killing of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor and the protests that followed, American ballet companies started talking a lot more about race. About the issues of diversity, equity and inclusion that organizations of all kinds were addressing, but also aesthetic assumptions, implicit biases and longstanding practices particular to ballet and its history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $3.8 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malala Yousafzai
title: Malala: I Fear for My Afghan Sisters
description: In the last two decades, millions of Afghan women and girls received an education. Now the future they were promised is in imminent danger.
content: In the last two decades, millions of Afghan women and girls received an education. Now the future they were promised is dangerously close to slipping away. The Taliban — who until losing power 20 years ago barred nearly all girls and women from attending school and doled out harsh punishment to those who defied them — are back in control. Like many women, I fear for my Afghan sisters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: India says it will prioritize Hindus and Sikhs for emergency visas to Afghans.
description: Officials did not say whether Muslims would also be considered.
content: India’s government said on Tuesday that it would prioritize taking in Hindus and Sikhs from Afghanistan — a move that drew comparisons to a contentious 2019 citizenship law, enacted under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, that discriminates against Muslims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Jones
title: #BamaRush, Explained
description: Freshmen at the University of Alabama offered a real time look at rush season. Their TikToks became must-see TV.
content: Her shoes? Steve Madden. Earrings? Kendra Scott. Her bracelets are from Shein; her purse, Target. Oh, and her necklace is “normal.” It’s Pref Night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: For a Better Pizza, Light Up the Grill
description: J. Kenji López-Alt makes the case for grilled pizza, one of the easiest ways (really!) to get restaurant-quality pizza at home.
content: SEATTLE — After I graduated from college, I decided to take a full-time job as a cook (a move that left my mother disappointed for well over a decade, until she finally read my byline in this newspaper). My job was as a pizza-maker at Cambridge 1, a minimalist bar in Harvard Square from the restaurateurs Matthew Curtis and Chris Lutes that served nothing but salads and pizzas that we cooked directly over a hot grill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘In the Same Breath’ Review: Wuhan 2019, or When Normalcy Ended
description: In her latest documentary, the director of “One Child Nation” revisits the pandemic as it unfolded in China as well as in the United States.
content: When you hear about filmmakers in conflict zones, you may flash on countries like Syria or Afghanistan. The movies produced in theaters of war often follow a similar arc: The documentarian parachutes in to take stock of a catastrophe. The focus tends to be on rubble, blood and suffering — the spectacle. In her short, stellar career, the Chinese filmmaker Nanfu Wang has repeatedly returned to a less obvious conflict zone in which the war for proverbial hearts and minds mostly takes place through state propaganda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Glittering Boots for a Brighter Fall
description: Sparkly, eye-catching platforms and high heels — in metallic leather or shimmering sequins — evince a sense of optimism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Breakthrough infections are forcing a change.
content: The Biden administration has decided that most Americans should get a coronavirus booster shot, our colleague Sharon LaFraniere reported last night. Officials are planning to announce the decision as early as this week, with doses beginning as early as mid-September for the most vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamsin Shaw
title: The Morally Troubling ‘Dirty Work’ We Pay Others to Do in Our Place
description: A new book by Eyal Press examines ethically fraught jobs on which our society depends and which we implicitly condone even as we pay other people to do them.
content: DIRTY WORKEssential Jobs and the Hidden Toll of Inequality in AmericaBy Eyal Press
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m an Art Therapist. Am I Guilty of Cultural Appropriation?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on who should be allowed to find their “spirit animals.”
content: I work as an art therapist at a hospital, where I invited a group of patients to participate in an exercise based on the practices of several Indigenous American cultures. I led participants on a guided mindfulness journey to find their spirit animals. Afterward, we discussed the meanings of their animals, and patients drew pictures of them and put them on a totem pole. We discussed the internal individual experience and the group experience. The patients seemed to get a lot out of the session. But I am a white male, and one patient questioned whether it was appropriate for me to do this exercise. She claimed that it was an example of “cultural appropriation.” Is she right? Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Real Estate Industry Works to Change Its Ways
description: Reckoning with its historical role in promoting racism in homeownership, real estate professionals are rewriting rules and working to help increase Black homeownership.
content: Earlier this summer, one day before the first ever Juneteenth federal holiday in the United States, Marcia Fudge, the secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, stood at a podium in Cleveland and made a bold pledge: By 2030, there will be 3 million new Black homeowners in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Ankara Print Dresses? These Aren’t Shakespeare’s ‘Merry Wives.’
description: Shakespeare in the Park is back, and Dede Ayite’s West African-influenced costume designs are just as lively as Jocelyn Bioh’s adaptation.
content: When Saheem Ali, the director of this summer’s Shakespeare in the Park production of “Merry Wives,” thought about which costume designer he wanted to create the clothes for the show, he knew immediately that it should be Dede Ayite. The two have been friends for years, and have worked together on “Twelfth Night” for the Public Mobile Unit, “Fires in the Mirror” at Signature Theater Company and the upcoming “Nollywood Dreams” at the MCC Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Diana Nguyen, Clare Toeniskoetter, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: America’s Miscalculations, Afghanistan’s Collapse
description: How misjudgments by the U.S. led to the stunningly fast takeover of the Taliban.
content: The last few days in Afghanistan have been chaotic, with the Taliban taking control of the capital, Kabul, much faster than the White House, journalists and even residents had expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Pink Siifu, a Shape-Shifting Musician With One Demand: Don’t Box Me In
description: The prolific 29-year-old rapper, singer and producer returned this month with “Gumbo’!,” a hat tip to the soulful Southern rap that inspired him.
content: In 2018, Livingston Matthews landed in New York for a series of gigs and was low on money after having to unexpectedly check a bag on his flight. So he hopped a subway turnstile, only to be detained by a police officer who wanted to put him in his place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Ellen Havre Weis, Whose Museum Put Pop Into Mythology, Dies at 64
description: The Museum of Modern Mythology, in San Francisco, which she helped found, posited that advertising figures have emerged as the pre-eminent mythical figures of our time.
content: Ellen Havre Weis, who helped create the popular Museum of Modern Mythology in San Francisco, which was based on the notion that the advertising characters who exist in modern life — the Jolly Green Giant, Colonel Sanders, Mr. Peanut — populate a mythology in their own right, died on July 27 at her home in Altadena, Calif. She was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Chris Cuomo of CNN breaks silence on his brother’s scandal.
description: “I tried to do the right thing,” the host told viewers, in his first public remarks since Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he would resign.
content: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s political career teetered, his brother, the TV host Chris Cuomo, kept silent, declining to address the matter on his CNN show and then leaving for what he described as a planned vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: It’s Time to Talk About ‘Hard Things’
description: Welcome to the world of Anna Sale — the host of “Death, Sex & Money” — where the topics that are the most painful to talk about are also the ripest for discussion.
content: — Anna Sale, the author of “Let’s Talk About Hard Things”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery
title: People Now Spend More at Amazon Than at Walmart
description: Proof that the online future has arrived: The biggest e-commerce company outside China has unseated the biggest brick-and-mortar seller.
content: SEATTLE — Amazon has eclipsed Walmart to become the world’s largest retail seller outside China, according to corporate and industry data, a milestone in the shift from brick-and-mortar to online shopping that has changed how people buy everything from Teddy Grahams to teddy bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The Taliban Are Back. Now Will They Restrain or Support Al Qaeda?
description: The United States invaded Afghanistan 20 years ago in response to terrorism, and many worry that Al Qaeda and other radical Islamist groups will again find safe haven there.
content: BRUSSELS — The United States and NATO invaded Afghanistan 20 years ago in response to the terrorist attacks of 9/11 by Al Qaeda, harbored by the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: What Constitutes Art Sales Under Duress? A Dispute Reignites the Question.
description: A fight over a landscape painting bought for Hitler is focused on the question of whether its sale was voluntary or forced by economic distress the Nazis helped create.
content: In 1938, the Jewish department-store magnate Max Emden, who left Germany before the Nazis took power, sold three city views by the 18th-century painter Bernardo Bellotto to an art buyer for Hitler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Taliban spokesman, in first news conference in Kabul, pledges no reprisals.
description: As the world looks on, fearful of a repeat of the Taliban’s brutal previous era, the insurgents are trying to rebrand themselves.
content: For nearly two decades, Zabihullah Mujahid was the voice of the Taliban, but only on Tuesday did the world get its first look at his face, when he appeared before reporters in a jam-packed Kabul briefing room to discuss what the insurgents plan to do with their newly won country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: He Spent 14 Years at Guantánamo. This Is His Story.
description: “Don’t Forget Us Here,” by Mansoor Adayfi with Antonio Aiello, is the memoir of a Yemeni man who claims he was kidnapped in Afghanistan, sold to the C.I.A. and sent to the detention camp in a case of mistaken identity.
content: DON’T FORGET US HERELost and Found at GuantánamoBy Mansoor Adayfi with Antonio Aiello
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Berger
title: This Breast Cancer Gene Is Less Well Known, but Nearly as Dangerous
description: PALB2 is not as well known as BRCA, but mutations of the gene can raise a woman’s risk for breast cancer almost as much.
content: For years, women with breast cancer in their families have been getting tested for mutations in two genes, known as BRCA1 and BRCA2, to determine whether they have a sharply elevated risk of the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Faculty at some U.S. state universities protest for more safety measures.
description: Administrators say their hands are tied by state laws and political realities. But a South Carolina court on Tuesday issued a ruling that may allow for mask mandates at the state’s public universities.
content: At Pennsylvania State University, the faculty senate passed a resolution expressing “no confidence” in the school’s plan to bring back students without requiring them to be vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Clemence
title: Is There Racism in the Deed to Your Home?
description: Racial covenants were designed to keep neighborhoods segregated. Some states are now making it easier to erase them from legal documents.
content: Last year, to celebrate the centennial of their charming Craftsman home, Kyona and Kenneth Zak repainted it in historically accurate colors — gray, bronze green and copper red. They commissioned beveled-glass windows to complement the original stained glass. And they visited the San Diego County Recorder, to have a line drawn through a sentence in their deed that once would have prohibited Ms. Zak, who is Black, from owning the home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Plotz
title: The Victorian Poet Who Sought to Capture Everyday Life in Her Verse
description: “Two-Way Mirror,” by Fiona Sampson, is the first biography of Elizabeth Barrett Browning in many years. It aims to restore the now overlooked poet’s reputation as a major innovator.
content: TWO-WAY MIRRORThe Life of Elizabeth Barrett BrowningBy Fiona Sampson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Lawmakers from both parties express fury over the withdrawal from Afghanistan.
description: If President Biden hoped to find cover from politicians in both parties who had reached a broad consensus on withdrawal, he was most likely disappointed.
content: President Biden’s unapologetic defense on Monday of his decisions in Afghanistan rallied some Democrats to his side, but the president still faces angry and increasingly public criticism from lawmakers in both parties over the chaos descending on Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Bill Ackman’s SPAC Gets Sued
description: The lawsuit could have far-reaching consequences for the entire blank-check industry.
content: Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, the special purpose acquisition company run by the billionaire hedge-fund investor Bill Ackman, got sued this morning in a novel case that could have far-reaching implications for the SPAC industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Abend
title: Denmark Now Has Two Little Mermaids. The Famous One Is Suing.
description: The heirs of the artist behind the Copenhagen landmark want a similar statue torn down. And they want compensation, too.
content: ASAA, Denmark — On a blustery day last week, Tina Pedersen and Jens Poulsen, two Danish vacationers, posed for pictures beside a statue of a mermaid. In some ways, the sculpture seemed familiar: Perched by a harbor, the mermaid rested the weight of her bare torso on one arm, and draped her piscine tail delicately over a rock. Yet Pedersen and Poulsen were not in Copenhagen; they were on their way to a beach vacation on the other side of Denmark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: It’s Never Too Late to Record Your First Album
description: For a celebrated architecture professor at the University of California, Berkeley, an album of 11 original songs, in a variety of genres, was eight decades in the making.
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a new series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Mujib Mashal
title: India’s Covid-19 Numbers Have Fallen. A Third Wave Still Looms.
description: Scientists are looking for signs that another variant could emerge in Delta’s wake, but limited sampling capabilities are hindering the search.
content: In the state of Maharashtra, one of the first places struck by India’s devastating second wave of Covid-19 earlier this year, scientists are anxiously looking for signs of a third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Laser Fusion Experiment Unleashes an Energetic Burst of Optimism
description: Even scientists who were skeptical of work at the National Ignition Facility called the results a success.
content: Scientists have come tantalizingly close to reproducing the power of the sun — albeit only in a speck of hydrogen for a fraction of a second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: The owner of Politico is said to be seeking $1 billion in a deal with Axel Springer.
description: Robert Allbritton, the owner of Politico, is weighing a lucrative payday against maintaining full control over a widely read Washington news site.
content: Politico, the Washington news site popular with Beltway power brokers, is seeking as much as $1 billion in a potential deal with the German publishing giant Axel Springer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Nike Renames the Alberto Salazar Building After Lifetime Ban
description: Salazar, the famed distance running coach, has been permanently barred from the sport by the U.S. Center for SafeSport for sexual and emotional misconduct.
content: Nike confirmed Tuesday that it had renamed the Alberto Salazar Building on its Beaverton, Ore., campus, whose namesake was the famed distance running coach who has been barred from the sport for sexual and emotional misconduct. The change is a stunning and perhaps complete termination of the relationship between Nike and Salazar, who have been tightly linked for nearly four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Jack Ewing
title: Days May Be Numbered for the World’s Oldest Bank
description: After performing poorly in a stress test, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, founded in 1472, could be swallowed by UniCredit.
content: SIENA, Italy — Last month Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, acquired another distinction: Europe’s weakest lender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: For America, and Afghanistan, the Post-9/11 Era Ends Painfully
description: The desperate scenes at the Kabul airport will now give Afghanistan a place in America’s national memory as another failed attempt to reshape a far-off land.
content: An era that began two decades ago with the shock of hijacked planes flying into American skyscrapers drew to a close this week with desperate Afghans clinging to American planes as they tried to escape the chaos of Kabul. Some fell; one was found dead in the landing gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mallika Rao
title: The Immortal Myth of the Unicorn
description: Over centuries, the legendary creature has become woven into the cultural imagination — and still fascinates as a symbol of the untamed.
content: In the fourth century B.C., a Greek physician named Ctesias described an animal that would become known as the unicorn: a large, pale blue-eyed ass with a crimson head and a horn of white, red and black, found only in India. Likely created from stories he heard while stationed in Persia (modern-day Iran), Ctesias’ “Indica” — a written catalog of the unknown world — shimmers with the sublime and the absurd: notes on a race of people with a single leg; descriptions of chimeric beasts. But it was the unicorn, possessor of what Ctesias described as a cinnabar-red anklebone, that remains his most enduring contribution. (The scholar Chris Lavers, author of 2009’s “The Natural History of Unicorns,” has written that Ctesias assembled the unicorn out of three animals indigenous to the region: the Indian rhinoceros, whose horn is associated with medicinal properties; the goatlike, horned chiru; and the reddish-and-white-colored kiang, a large wild ass.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Break Up Big Chicken
description: Silicon Valley is in the spotlight, but harmful concentrations of corporate power are mostly found in older and less glamorous industries.
content: President Biden wants to lead a revival of antitrust enforcement, a campaign aimed most obviously at curbing the behavior of feral tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Tropical Depression Fred touches off tornadoes in the Carolinas.
description: The storm system crossed the Southeast on Tuesday after making landfall in Florida.
content: The remnants of Tropical Depression Fred touched off a chain reaction of tornadoes and tornado warnings across the Southeast on Tuesday, especially in the Carolinas, one day after the storm system made landfall along Florida's Gulf Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Giulia Heyward and Holly Secon
title: ‘We Haven’t Slept, We Haven’t Eaten’: U.S. Afghans Watch the Chaos With Horror
description: In California, where many Afghans resettled after the American invasion, those who worked with the United States fear for relatives left behind.
content: SACRAMENTO — They call themselves the lucky people, the Afghans who made it out in time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Body Parts Found in Landing Gear of Flight From Kabul, Officials Say
description: Harrowing video of the chaos, recorded by the Afghan news media, has circulated around the world. The Air Force said the episode was under investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Air Force acknowledged on Tuesday that human body parts were found in the wheel well of an American military C-17 cargo plane that took flight amid chaos at Hamid Karzai International Airport in Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Azi Paybarah
title: Chicago, New Mexico and airports turn to mask requirements as virus cases rise.
description: They join a growing list of metropolises and states that now require masks in public indoor places.
content: As the highly contagious Delta variant fuels a sharp rise in cases around the United States, more indoor mask mandates are returning or being extended: for Chicagoans, New Mexicans and, now until next year, any American using public transportation or visiting an airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How Amazon Won Shopping
description: Amazon might not be the best shopping site, but using it can feel like magic.
content: This is a preview of the On Tech With Shira Ovide newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox three times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: What Is Redlining?
description: The term has come to mean racial discrimination of any kind in housing, but it comes from government maps that outlined areas where Black residents lived and were therefore deemed risky investments.
content: In recent years, the term “redlining” has become shorthand for many types of historic race-based exclusionary tactics in real estate — from racial steering by real estate agents (directing Black home buyers and renters to certain neighborhoods or buildings and away from others) to racial covenants in many suburbs and developments (barring Black residents from buying homes). All of which contributed to the racial segregation that shaped the way America looks today.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Veterans, Pain, Anguish and Sorrows
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 17, 2021
content: “I just can’t help thinking about what a waste it is. I can’t allow myself to think about how after all that blood and treasure, it ends like this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut
title: Haiti Quake Toll Leaps to Nearly 2,000 Dead as Rain Pelts Survivors
description: The new casualty figures from Saturday’s quake, including 10,000 injured, come as victims struggled with a storm deluge that could complicate relief efforts.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The death and injury tolls leapt by many hundreds on Tuesday from the weekend earthquake in Haiti’s southern peninsula, as survivors soaked from Tropical Storm Grace struggled to keep safe in makeshift shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Every Relationship Has Its Hiccups, Yet…’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My sister is younger than I am — fiercer and more mercurial, too. She lives in a city 200 miles north of mine. We text regularly but still miss and mystify each other. One night this June, home together for the first time in six months, our parents asleep, she whispered my name: “Come see the stars.” I got out of bed and joined her underneath the infinite sky, our necks craned in reverence. “I needed a reminder that they existed and thought you might too,” she said. I did. Star-struck, we went to bed. — Amy Guay
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
title: Intelligence Warned of Afghan Military Collapse, Despite Biden’s Assurances
description: Even as the president was telling the public that Kabul was unlikely to fall, intelligence assessments painted a grimmer picture.
content: WASHINGTON — Classified assessments by American spy agencies over the summer painted an increasingly grim picture of the prospect of a Taliban takeover of Afghanistan and warned of the rapid collapse of the Afghan military, even as President Biden and his advisers said publicly that was unlikely to happen as quickly, according to current and former American government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Sacklers Threaten to Pull Out of Opioid Settlement Without Broad Legal Immunity
description: In a rare court appearance, David Sackler said he and his family would withdraw their pledge to pay $4.5 billion, unless they are shielded from lawsuits related to Purdue Pharma.
content: A scion of the Sackler family, the billionaire owners of Purdue Pharma, vowed in court on Tuesday that the family would walk away from a $4.5 billion pledge to help communities nationwide that have been devastated by the opioid epidemic, unless a judge grants it immunity from all current and future civil claims associated with the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Home Depot Punished Worker for Black Lives Matter Logo, Labor Board Says
description: A former employee said Home Depot told him to stop wearing a Black Lives Matter logo or quit, according to a National Labor Relations Board complaint.
content: Home Depot forced a worker to quit after he wore a slogan supporting the Black Lives Matter movement on his apron, and it threatened to punish other employees who tried to bring attention to racial harassment, according to a complaint issued by an office of the National Labor Relations Board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 8: On ‘If You Paid Your Debt to Society, You Should Be Allowed to Work’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Francisco, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We received 1,089 entries from students from around the world for the eighth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Francisco, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we recognize below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail Sales Fell in July, Highlighting a Rocky Economic Recovery
description: The 1.1 percent decline was sharper than economists had expected and came as sales of cars and home goods dropped.
content: Retail sales dropped in July, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday, a sign that consumer spending was hampered amid an uneven economic recovery from pandemic-induced restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vaccine Mandate for Indoor Venues Starts in New York City

author: By Jacquelynn Kerubo
title: What Gentrification Means for Black Homeowners
description: In historically Black neighborhoods, owners selling their homes on the open market have to grapple with the fact that accepting the highest bid could mean another step toward Black displacement.
content: Nostalgia isn’t enough to keep Thomas Holley, 74, in the Crown Heights brownstone he has lived in for more than 58 years.
